newsitem.title: USA: U.S. crudes ease late on Iraq, finds API support.
newsitem.headline: U.S. crudes ease late on Iraq, finds API support.

text.p: U.S. crudes eased Wednesday on diminished concerns over Iraqi troop incursions but were later aided by relatively large draws in overall crude oil stocks.
News that Iraqi troops had pulled out of Kurdish regions in northern Iraq after U.S. air strikes later in the day, brought NYMEX crude prices down from morning highs.
Outright prices also revived on American Petroleum Institute (API) data showing a 5.6 million barrel draw in crude stocks and a drop in imports to 6.7 million barrels.
October West Texas Intermediate/Cushing was at $23.20-30 a barrel, with the Oct/Nov roll steady around 70 cts.
Domestic trade was moderately active in narrowly softer ranges with activity spread across the grades.
Light Louisiana Sweet/St. James moved several times at WTI plus 33 cents, barely changed from Tuesday. WTI/Midland traded between plus eight and 10 cents, modestly softer than Tuesday.
Eugene Island was done at a negative $1.03 and $1.05 to WTI/Cushing, while West Texas Sour/Midland moved at minus $1.20/1.22, both at relatively stable levels.
WTI/Cushing Postings Plus was the most active, trading between $2.33 and $2.41, and drawing refiner short covering amid a steeper price backwardation recently.
Elswehere, Hurricane Fran threatening the U.S. Atlantic coast also lent some psychological support, although no disruptions were reported to refinery operations or shipping.
